Doctor prescribed Lipitor/Synthroid

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎02-23-2013 09:32 PM

I saw my doctor yesterday and she put me on Lipitor for high cholesterol.  I would like to hear from anyone who has taken this medication and what your experiences are, please.

 

I'm very wary about starting new medicines because I have a lot of adverse drug reactions but I know my cholesterol levels have really gotten high in the last couple of years since my diabetes diagnosis.  My A1C is 5.8 to 6.0  each visit though.

 

She also prescribed Synthroid for low thyroid.  I'd lke to know about anyone's experiences with this also.  I'm definitely nervous about starting these two medications.  Thanks.

Report Inappropriate Content

Re: Doctor prescribed Lipitor/Synthroid

Options
  • Mark as New
  • Bookmark
  • Subscribe to Direct Replies to This Post
  • Subscribe to RSS Feed
  • Highlight
  • Print
  • Email to a Friend
  • Report Inappropriate Content

‎02-23-2013 10:28 PM

I have taken Synthroid for the last 7 years.  I have been on statins for the last 2.

 

First of all, because there is a strong connection between low thyroid and high cholesterol, I would not recommend starting both medicines at once.  I would start the synthroid first, and see what happens to your cholesterol levels when your thyroid levels come into line.  Many people experience an improvement in their cholesterol numbers when their thyroid is properly regulated.

 

Synthroid shouldn't cause side effects unless you are taking too much.  If you are having problems with fatigue, constipation, dry skin--it should make these things better.

 

Adjusting the medications for thyroid takes weeks to months, depending on how far off your levels are.  The cholesterol levels can take some time after that to settle.  These may also respond more readily to diet and exercise after your thyroid is regulated.

 

Keep in mind, the damage from high cholesterol (if you believe that it really is the culprit) takes decades to develop.  Waiting several months to see what happens to these numbers as your thyroid is regulated is not a long time in the scheme of things.

 

I took lipitor first (my cholesterol stayed high, well after my thryoid numbers were good).  I did well on it for 10 months before I began to experience the large muscle pain that they list as a side effect.  After going off of it for 3 months, I tried crestor instead.  Lipitor (and its cousins) is fat soluble, and tends to be stored by the body.  Crestor (and its cousins) is water soluble and tends not to be stored as much.  Patients report fewer muscle problems with the water soluble statins, but they don't work as well as the fat soluble type, so the net result is that patients often take a higher dose.

 

Most of the listed side effects of statins--nausea and GI distress were mine--go away with in a couple weeks of starting the medication.

 

I would suggest you research and discuss Niacin with your doctor.  Slow release niacin is coming back into favor--it was the original cholesterol drug before there were statins.  The beauty of it is that it lowers your LDL, raises your HDL and lowers your triglycerides.  It is a vitamin--so it can be bought with out a prescription--and is much less expensive than a statin.  The primary side effect that bothers people is "flushing" which many people experience until they are acclimated to the drug (basically you turn red all over for about an hour, about an hour after you take it).  It generally does not have the muscle issues that statins do.  I take niacin as well as crestor.

 

I will add that both statins and high dose niacin require monitoring of liver and kidney function.  In diabetics and prediabetics they are known to raise blood glucose values by a small percentage as well.

June 2015 A1C 6.0%
December 2014 A1C 6.0%
September 2014 A1C 5.9%
March 2014 A1C 6.0%
December 2013 A1C 6.2%
June 2013 A1C 6.0%
December 2012 FBG 142, A1C 5.3%
June 2012 FBG: 154, A1C 5.9%

No meds--normal weight, mod-carb diet, exercise

Re: Doctor prescribed Lipitor/Synthroid

‎02-24-2013 12:11 AM

My thyroid has always been good so I have no experience with Synthroid.

 

I have taken a statin for close to ten years now. At first it was Lipitor, and then later we switched to other generic statins to save money. I had no side effects with Lipitor. I thought maybe my leg cramps were due to some of the other statins, and switched from one to the other various times, and stopped them for a while because of the leg cramps, which never went away when I switched or stopped, and never increased when I started again. After a while a doctor told me that the muscle pain at times discussed as a side-effect of statins, which manufacturers say represents a small percentage of those taking the drug, actually is a more general ache than the leg cramps I was having--which are usually caused by an electrolyte imbalance. But I had tried supplementing with all of those, I thought, until I realized that I had never tried more sodium. That has made all the difference in the world--they are much less frequent now, and less severe when I have them, and a couple of crackers stops them in their tracks.

 

My leg cramps were actually caused by adopting a healthier diet, with virtually no processed foods, which apparently account for 710% of the sodium intake in the American diet. I was one of those very few people who was not getting enough sodium--and also one of the 80% for whom more sodium does not cause higher blood pressure.

Morris

Diagnosed Type 2, with an A1c of 11.4 in 2003; averaging a 5.0 A1c since then with diet, exercise and Glipizide XL + meds for blood pressure and cholesterol.  A bit dated, but scroll down on this page if you want to know more ...

‎02-24-2013 04:44 PM

newdiabetic wrote:

I saw my doctor yesterday and she put me on Lipitor for high cholesterol.  I would like to hear from anyone who has taken this medication and what your experiences are, please.

 

I'm very wary about starting new medicines because I have a lot of adverse drug reactions but I know my cholesterol levels have really gotten high in the last couple of years since my diabetes diagnosis.  My A1C is 5.8 to 6.0  each visit though.

 

She also prescribed Synthroid for low thyroid.  I'd lke to know about anyone's experiences with this also.  I'm definitely nervous about starting these two medications.  Thanks.

 

All medications have possible side effects, but not all patients suffer from them.

 

Important Information About LIPITOR (atorvastatin calcium) Tablets

 

What Are the Possible Side Effects of LIPITOR (atorvastatin calcium) Tablets?

LIPITOR (atorvastatin calcium) tablets can cause serious side effects. These side effects have happened only to a small number of people. Your doctor can monitor you for them. These side effects usually go away if your dose is lowered or LIPITOR is stopped.

These serious side effects include:

  • Muscle problems. LIPITOR can cause serious muscle problems that can lead to kidney problems, including kidney failure. You have a higher chance for muscle problems if you are taking certain other medicines with LIPITOR.
  • Liver problems. LIPITOR can cause liver problems. Your doctor may do blood tests to check your liver before you start taking LIPITOR, and while you take it.

Call your doctor right away if:

  • You have muscle problems like weakness, tenderness, or pain that happen without a good reason, especially if you also have a fever or feel more tired than usual
  • You have allergic reactions including swelling of the face, lips, tongue, and/or throat that may cause difficulty in breathing or swallowing, which may require treatment right away
  • You experience nausea and vomiting
  • You pass brown or dark-colored urine
  • You feel more tired than usual
  • Your skin and whites of your eyes get yellow
  • You have stomach pain
  • You have an allergic skin reaction

In clinical studies, patients reported the following common side effects while taking LIPITOR (atorvastatin calcium) tablets:

  • Diarrhea
  • Upset stomach
  • Muscle and joint pain
  • Alterations in some laboratory tests

The following additional side effects have been reported with LIPITOR (atorvastatin calcium) tablets:

  • Tiredness
  • Tendon problems

Talk to your doctor or pharmacist if you have side effects that bother you or that will not go away. These are not all the side effects of LIPITOR (atorvastatin calcium) tablets. Ask your doctor or pharmacist for a complete list.

 

I have highlighted the one which led me to quit lipitor several years ago. My problems were not severe, but sufficient for me to start searching and reading. I admit my bias. Since that time I have done a lot of reading on cholesterol and statins. I will never take one again regardless of my lipid levels.

Cheers, Alan, Type 2, d&e metformin 2000mg, Australia.
Everything in Moderation - Except Laughter.
There is nothing I could eat I like more than my eyes.
Type 2 Diabetes - A Personal Journey(latest: Fat: The New Health Paradigm)
Born Under a Wandering Star (Latest: Ella to Kandy, Sri Lanka)

‎02-25-2013 08:56 AM

Watch out for side effects from the Lipitor!  Some don't have any, but for me it was like having rocks buried in my muscles.  Every movement hurt.  I quit taking the stuff pretty quickly.

 

I was given the Lipitor before my T2 diagnosis.  Once my BG came under control, all of my cholesterol numbers improved to a point where the Lipitor wasn't necessary anyway.

 

My wife takes thyroid meds, but I don't think she's on synthroid any longer.  Don't be surprised if you have to make adjustments in the prescription.  It doesn't take much synthroid to make big changes, so its not unusual to have to increase or decrease the dose - and it may happen several times.

 

Type 2 - complicated by surgery for pancreatic cancer

‎02-25-2013 09:54 AM

New,

 

I have been on synthroid for more than 20 years. My dosage was reduced because of too high thyroid reading, my dose is .112 mg now. Thyroid helps increase energy and metabolism and is thus good for a diabetic.

 

I have been on Lipitor for more than 15 years, low dose 10 mg. When I tried to go to 20 mgs, I had some pain issues. Keeping LDL low is essential for diabetics since CVD is the complication that kills  most type-2 diabetics, 65%. Most doctors and the ADA, FDA, and CDC indicate that glucose control does not prevent CVD in type-2 diabetics; the medications that do are those that lower cholesterol and blood pressure. High doses of Lipitor have been shown to raise glucose levels slightly, but most doctor think the benefits of Lipitor greatly out weigh the risks. As the dose of Lipitor is raise the benefit gain gets less. I have been quite happy with my 10 mg and when I tried to go off it, I had a 30% gain in LDL; so, I went back on it and continue to take it today.

 

Chuck

I've no personal experience with the synthroid (though my sigot takes it), but like the others have also never heard of problems if the dosage is appropriate.  My doc finally told me to start taking Niacin to get my LDL numbers a little lower (total is good) even though the labs say it is at the very bottom of the scale.

‎02-25-2013 01:46 PM

I wiil chime in about synthroid. I have taken it for several years, and thyroid disease seems more predominate in diabetics as a group. The trick is for your doctor to get the right amount of Med for you....this will require fairly frequent blood tests, and it is a Med you will be on for the rest of your life. Your thyroid is your bodies thermostat...controlling the furnace so to speak. If your thyrold is low then you are cold, sluget and weight loss is difficult. To high and you can have sweats and heart palpatations. There is a host of other symptoms, so pay very close attention to your levels. Good luck!
Thanks Rick

Diagnosed T2 4/4/2011

06/27/2011, A1c 5.6

1/14/2012, A1c 5.4

Managed by diet and exercise along....former insulin and Metformin user

‎02-25-2013 02:41 PM

The issue of Lipitor or using any other statins is funny to me. Diabetes is always associated with high cholesterol problems. Now, if one is taking good care of lowering blood sugar (as you are doing pretty well with such A1C level), then, high cholesterol would not be a problem as long as you are taking good care of your diet and exercising. 

Now, the only problem of yours is thyroid, which can be treated appropriately, so, all other problems would be resolved. The use of statins (Lipitor) is associated with high blood sugar (or diabetes). So, this is the funniest part I would like to underline: you are already a diabetic, but adding Lipitor would alter your blood sugar more. Talk to your doctor about this side effect.

‎02-25-2013 04:11 PM

Lead,

 

Tried Niacin once, think it bother my stomach and caused cramping in my cavs; so, only took a couple of pills. If I were in target range, I would not take additional medications. I am very big on taking only the medication that I need and in the lowest dosage possible. Lipitor is a fine example where high doses are associated with higher blood sugar and in some cases muscle pain. Everything in moderation for me, except maybe exercise, but to me my exercise levels are right.

 

Chuck
